FacilityName: Pioneer Americas LLC Tacoma Bleach Plant

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Pioneer Americas LLC (?Pioneer?) Tacoma, Washington, Bleach facility is committed to the safety and well being of its employees, neighboring community, and the environment.  Pioneer is an active member of the Chlorine Institute, an industry group that develops technology for the safe handling and management of chlorine.  Pioneer also participates in the Canadian Chemical Producers? Association Responsible Care? initiative.  Responsible Care? is the industry?s effort to reach out and dialogue with the public regarding our environmental, health and safety programs and to receive input from the community on issues of concern.

Stationary Source

The site produces sodium hypochlorite (bleach) from chlorine and sodium hydroxide (caustic) and repackages chlorine into one-ton containers and 150-pound cylinders.  The site also distributes sulfur dioxide.  These chemicals provide important benefits in critical applications such as water purification and household disinfectants.  Pioneer?s policy is to implement reasonable measures to prevent a release of a hazardous material from occurring, to provide early detection of a release in the unlikely event that one would occur, and to have in place a contingency plan to respond promptly yet safely to such a release.

The site also produces fabric softeners and household ammonia.  None of the chemicals used in this manufacturing appears on site at a level such that they fall under the Risk Management Program (?RMP?) rule.

Regulated Substances Handled

This Risk Management Plan has been prepared to address the handling of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Pioneer Tacoma Bleach facility.

Liquefied chlorine is received in 90-ton rail cars and repackaged into one-ton containers and 150-pound cylinders.  It is also used in the manufacture of bleach.  Customers use both chlorine and bleach to treat drinking water, wastewater, swimming pool water and industrial water t

o eliminate and/or prevent the growth of harmful organisms.

Sulfur dioxide is received in ton containers and 150-pound cylinders and is stored on site for distribution to customers.  No repackaging takes place.  Sulfur dioxide is also used in water treatment.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

Pioneer has a comprehensive release prevention program, meeting the Federal RMP Prevention Program and OSHA Process Safety Management (?PSM?) requirements.  We have physical safeguards in place to prevent a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide.  We also follow best industry practices for the design and construction of equipment, piping and instrumentation.  Our process design includes expansion bottles and/or rupture disks and pressure switches to safeguard against hydrostatic overpressure of equipment and piping.

Five Year Accident History

An accident involving a small release of chlorine that resulted in an injury occurred on October 25, 2002.  An operator connected a hose and yoke to a liquid chlorine valve to check for pressure.  The liquid valve was not closed.  He applied vacuum in preparation of attaching the line to a gas valve.  The gas yoke disconnected from the plug, releasing a short burst of liquid chlorine at chest height and about one foot away from the operator.  The operator was transported to the local clinic and was treated for chlorine exposure.

Emergency Response Program

Pioneer has a comprehensive emergency response program that includes detection, alarm, shutdown, containment and scrubbing systems to halt and/or mitigate a release.  In the unlikely event that a release cannot be controlled completely with these systems, Pioneer has an Emergency Response Team trained and equipped to respond safely to a release in accordance with a written Emergency Response Plan.  Pioneer has worked closely with the Tacoma Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Committee (?LEPC?) in developing its Emergency Response Plan.  Pioneer has also been working cl

osely with Pierce County Emergency Management in their development of the Threat Response System designed to provide detailed site information to emergency responders.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Pioneer has made significant changes to improve safety, including the expansion of both the coverage and functionality of the chlorine monitor system, the addition of video surveillance cameras, upgrades to the chlorine vent and disposal system and additional interlocks and automatic shutdown devices.  Future plans for improved safety include the installation of a chlorine emergency scrubber system, expansion of the video surveillance system, upgrades and expansion of the tank level control system and additional upgrades to the chlorine vent and disposal system
